coredata.dc:title: Defective C3N4 frameworks coordinated diatomic copper catalyst: Towards mild oxidation of methane to C1 oxygenates
coredata.dc:creator: Yang, Nating
Zhao, Yonghui
Wu, Ping
Liu, Guojuan
Sun, Fanfei
Ma, Jingyuan
Jiang, Zheng
Sun, Yuhan
Zeng, Gaofeng
coredata.dc:description: Mild conversion of CH4 to value-added chemicals remains a grand challenge due to its chemical inertness. We report the N-defective C3N4 confined diatomic Cu (Cu2@C3N4-D) catalysts for the efficient oxidation of CH4 to C1 oxygenates at low temperature. With photo-irradiation, the carbon atoms neighbouring defects of C3N4 can anchor the second Cu by Cu-C2N bonding. Cu2@C3N4-D exhibits C1-oxygenates STY up to 4878 μmol gcat −1 h−1 with TOF of 83 h−1 at 50 °C, which is 300% higher than that of single atomic catalysts and even better than the reported noble-metal catalysts. The catalyst stability is also proved. Both experiments and computations demonstrate that the diatomic Cu pairs are toughly packed in asymmetrical [N3-Cu]···[Cu-C2N] with + 1 charge for Cu, endowing the catalyst with unique synergistic effects on CH4 activation. It provides a simple way to construct active sites with well-controlled atom number and enlightens the defect functionalization for catalyst design.

Methane selective oxidation
G-C3N4

(C) STY of C1 oxygenates and TOF on C3N4-D, Cu(NO3)2, Cu1@C3N4-D1 (0.15 wt% Cu), Cu1@C3N4-D2 (0.29 wt% Cu), Cu2@C3N4-D1(0.20 wt% Cu) and Cu2@C3N4-D2 (0.38 wt%). (D) Reusability of Cu1@C3N4-D1 and Cu2@C3N4-D1.

(A) Charge differences (iso-surface value 0.005 e Å−3) for Cu2@C3N4-D (Blue and yellow iso-surfaces stand for the negative and positive charges, respectively). (B) The calculated binding energies (E b) between Cu and substrates. AC-HAADF STEM images of (C) Cu2@C3N4-D1, (D) Cu2@C3N4-D2, and (E) Cu1@C3N4-D1. (F) and (G) Atomic distance from the selected areas in (C) and (D), respectively. (H) Elemental distribution of C, N and Cu on Cu2@C3N4-D1. Scale bars are 1 nm for C-E and 10 nm for H, respectively.

(A) Cu K-edge XANES, (B) First derivation of the Cu K-edge XANES, (C) Fourier-transformed k3-weighted EXAFS spectra for Cu K-edge of Cu2@C3N4-D1, Cu2@C3N4-D2 and Cu1@C3N4-D1 together with references at R-space. (D) EXAFS fitting parameters of samples.

head.ce:title: Defective C3N4 frameworks coordinated diatomic copper catalyst: Towards mild oxidation of methane to C1 oxygenates

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Mild conversion of CH4 to value-added chemicals remains a grand challenge due to its chemical inertness. We report the N-defective C3N4 confined diatomic Cu (Cu2@C3N4-D) catalysts for the efficient oxidation of CH4 to C1 oxygenates at low temperature. With photo-irradiation, the carbon atoms neighbouring defects of C3N4 can anchor the second Cu by Cu-C2N bonding. Cu2@C3N4-D exhibits C1-oxygenates STY up to 4878 μmol gcat −1 h−1 with TOF of 83 h−1 at 50 °C, which is 300% higher than that of single atomic catalysts and even better than the reported noble-metal catalysts. The catalyst stability is also proved. Both experiments and computations demonstrate that the diatomic Cu pairs are toughly packed in asymmetrical [N3-Cu]···[Cu-C2N] with + 1 charge for Cu, endowing the catalyst with unique synergistic effects on CH4 activation. It provides a simple way to construct active sites with well-controlled atom number and enlightens the defect functionalization for catalyst design.

We report the synthesis of N-defective C3N4 defined diatomic Cu pairs (Cu2@C3N4-D) catalysts with a facile photo-irradiation for the efficient oxidation of CH4 to C1 oxygenates at low temperature. The catalysts exhibit 300% higher activity than that of single atomic Cu1@C3N4-D catalysts.
ga1

ce:section.ce:para: Upgrading methane (CH4) to transportable and storable liquid chemicals is the mainstay of gas chemical industry [1]. However, the selective activation and conversion of CH4 remains a grand challenge because CH4 is the most stable hydrocarbon with strong C-H bond strength (439 kJ mol−1) [1]. Commercially, the CH4 conversion is an indirect process combining steam reforming and Fischer-Tropsch reactions, requiring intensive investment and energy consumption [1]. Although several routes of direct CH4 conversion to chemicals have been developed, they are still limited by the demanding reaction conditions, like high temperature being necessary for the oxidative coupling of methane and non-oxidative aromatization of CH4 or strongly corrosive conditions being unavoidable for the oleum-catalyzed CH4 conversion to methanol [2–4]. Therefore, it is highly desired to develop active catalysts for CH4 direct oxidation to value-added chemicals under mild conditions [5,6]. Supported single metal atom catalysts (SACs) are reported to be more efficient for CH4 selective oxidation than their support-free cations or nanoparticles [7,8]. For instance, single site Rh1O5 anchored in ZSM-5 frameworks can effectively activate CH4 and O2 and then couple with CO to produce acetic acid, being 1000 times more active than unsupported Rh cations [9]. Similarly, single Rh on ZrO2 is able to selectively activate CH4 to generate CH3OH with the help of H2O2, while the reaction on Rh nanoparticles can only produce CO2 [10]. The nature of support is also essential for the catalytic performance of SACs [11–15]. For instance, Cr1/TiO2 outperforms other single Cr atoms supported by SiO2, CeO2, Fe2O3, and TS-1 for the selective oxidation of CH4 [16]. In addition to zeolites and metal oxides, various supports such as metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [17] and graphene [18] have been used to anchor the SACs through providing O- or N-based ligands. However, it is noted that SACs suffer from structural simplicity and lack of synergistic active sites for the activation of reactants. The catalytic properties of catalysts with diatomic or slightly larger metal atom assemblies may dramatically differ from SACs, through enabling of synergistic effects [19,20].

The double-/triple- atom catalysts confined in zeolites [21–25] or MOFs [17,26,27] showed higher activity for CH4 oxidation. Hutchings et al. reported that the di-iron center of Fe/ZSM-5 can activate H2O2 and CH4 to produce C1 oxygenates at low temperature [21]. The di-copper or di-nickel atoms confined in zeolites are also active for CH4 oxidation in the gas phase reaction at mild conditions [22–25]. As particulate and soluble CH4 monooxygenase enzymes possess high activity for CH4 activation, various biomimetic catalysts for CH4 oxidation are realized by incorporating double- / triple- atoms into MOFs, such as oxo-bridged Fe dimers on MIL-53, bis(μ-oxo) di-copper ligated on MOF-808 and trimeric Cu oxide on NU-1000 [17,26,27]. Obviously these di- / tri-atomic catalysts for CH4 activation are mostly confined in zeolites or MOFs. The 3D micropores suppress the mass transfer in the reaction. Moreover, the unique surface properties of zeolites, like intrinsic hydrophilic nature, lead to strong adsorption of reagents and products [17]. On the other hand, MOFs suffer from the destruction or partial decomposition under the reaction conditions [17,28]. Therefore, the appropriate support, which can offer not only coordination sites for the fixation of diatoms but also low diffusion resistance and weak interactions for reagents, are highly promising to improve the activity of diatomic catalyst for CH4 oxidation. Carbon nitride (C3N4) is a potential support that has shown activity for CH4 oxidation to C1-C2 oxygenates by photocatalysis [29].

Herein, we report the fabrication of diatomic Cu on defective g-C3N4 (Cu2@C3N4-D) for methane selective oxidation at 50 °C. The nitrogen vacancies containing C3N4-D can provide three sp2-hybridized N atoms to anchor one Cu atom. Upon light irradiation, two C and one sp2 N near the N-vacancy can capture the second Cu atom. The Cu2@C3N4-D yields 4878 μmol g−1 h−1 C1 oxygenated products, which is much higher than that of single atoms Cu1@C3N4-D and the reported SACs.

g-C3N4 was synthesized by pyrolyzing cyanoguanidine (Alfa Aesar) at 550 °C for 4 h in air, which then was exfoliated by ball-milling at 600 rpm for 16 h. The defective C3N4 (C3N4-D) was synthesized by heating g-C3N4 at 620 °C for 6 h in N2. Cu2@C3N4-D was prepared by a photo-irradiation associated method. In a typical synthesis of Cu2@C3N4-D1, 120 mg of C3N4-D and 0.018 mmol of Cu(NO3)2 (Alfa Aesar) were dispersed in 30 mL ultrapure water and stirred for 3 h, which was transferred into a Petri dish and then frozen in liquid nitrogen. The frozen sample was irradiated with Xe light (300 W) for 15 min. The catalyst was washed by water and dried at 80 °C. Cu2@C3N4-D2 were prepared by the same procedure by using 0.09 mmol of Cu(NO3)2. The single atomic catalysts, Cu1@C3N4-D1 and Cu1@C3N4-D2, were prepared by the same procedure without photo irradiation.

CH4 oxidation was performed in a stainless-steel autoclave containing a 50 mL Teflon liner vessel. 10 mg catalyst, 9.7 mL ultrapure water and 0.285 mL H2O2 (5 mmol) were added in the vessel. The well-sealed reactor was purged with CH4 and then charged with 95% CH4/5% Ar to 3 MPa. The autoclave was stirred at 800 rpm and kept at 50 °C for 30 min. Then the autoclave was cooled to below 10 °C. The gas phase was measured by a gas chromatography (GC). 500 μL liquid phase product, 100 μL D2O, and 100 μL 5 mM 3-(trimethylsilyl)-1-propanesulfonic acid sodium salt (DSS) was added into nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) tube. Liquid phase was detected by 1 H NMR on Bruker AVANCE III 600 MHz with the signals of methanol (CH3OH, δ = 3.35 ppm), methyl hydroperoxide (CH3OOH, δ = 3.85 ppm), and hydroxylated methyl hydroperoxide (HOCH2OOH, δ = 5.04 ppm). 13C NMR, 13C distortionless enhancement of polarisation transfer (DEPT)-135 test: The experiment was carried out by using 1 MPa 13CH4. 50 mg Cu2 @C3N4-D was suspended in 10 mL 0.5 M H2O2 aqueous solution and reacted under stirring at 50 °C for 1 h. 500 μL obtained liquid phase product, 100 μL D2O, and 100 μL 5 mM DSS were added into NMR tube. The signals of CH3OH, CH3OOH and HOCH2OOH are located at 49 ppm, 65 ppm and 93 ppm in the 13 C NMR and 13 C DEPT-135.

The structure of catalysts was measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Ultima IV). The morphologies were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin (FEI) and JEOL 200F equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) at 200 kV. The surface chemistry of catalysts was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha). The measurements of X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of Cu K-edge were carried out on the XAFS station of BL14W1 and BL11B beamlines of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility in Shanghai Advanced Research Institute. N2 sorption was collected on a physical adsorption analyzer (TriStar II 3020). The metal content was measured via an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer Optima 8000). CH4 temperature-programmed desorption (CH4-TPD) was performed on a chemical adsorption analyzer (Autochem II 2920).

All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [30]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [31] was applied to treat the exchange correlation energy with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh (PBE) of functional [32]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) [33] method was employed to describe electron-ion interactions. The structural model of the Cu2@C3N4-D surface was constructed by introducing two Cu in the pore of tri-s-triazine with one N vacancy, that is, bonding one Cu in the N vacancy site with two C and one N and bonding the other Cu with three N together. The structural model of the Cu1@C3N4-D surface was constructed by forming three Cu–N bonds in tri-s-triazine with one N vacancy. The structural model of the Cu1@C3N4 surface was constructed by bonding Cu with three N. All geometries were fully optimized with a plane wave energy cutoff of 400 eV and convergence of energy and forces were set to 1 × 10−4 eV and 0.05 eV/Å, respectively. 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grid generated with the Monkhorst−Pack [34] scheme was used. Transition states were obtained by initially applying the force reversed method [35], and further optimizing using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) [36]. Transition states were confirmed by vibrational analysis yielding one imaginary frequency.

ce:section.ce:section-title: CH4 oxidation over diatomic Cu catalysts
ce:section.ce:para: As illustrated in Fig. 1 A & B, the preparation of Cu2@C3N4-D involves creating defective C3N4 (C3N4-D) and anchoring Cu atoms into the C3N4-D frameworks. C3N4-D with nitrogen vacancies (Nvac) was firstly realized via a thermal treatment (Fig. 1A). With charge attraction, Cu2+ tends to selectively interact with three N-2C (N bonding with two C atoms) sites to fix one Cu atom because the N-2C site is negatively charged and the C-2N (C bonding with two N atoms) is positively charged in the regular C3N4 skeleton (Fig. 1B) [37,38]. Sequentially, the C atoms neighboring Nvac adopted the photogenerated-electrons under the irradiation of an Xe lamp [37], which is then able to capture another Cu2+ to form a di-copper N3-Cu···Cu–C2N structure (i.e. Cu2@C3N4-D). The distance between the di-copper is calculated as ~0.25 nm (Fig. 1B). For comparison, single atomic Cu catalysts, Cu1@C3N4-D, were obtained via the same method but without the irradiation. The Cu contents determined by ICP are 0.20 wt% (Cu2@C3N4-D1), 0.38 wt% (Cu2@C3N4-D2), 0.15 wt% (Cu1@C3N4-D1), and 0.29 wt% (Cu1@C3N4-D2), respectively. All these catalysts have similar specific surface area, fluctuating around 25–29 m2 g−1 (Fig. S1).

In the reaction, C1 oxygenate products, including CH3OH, CH3OOH and HOCH2OOH, are detectable by 1H, 13C NMR and gas chromatography (Figs. S2-S4). Cu2@C3N4-D1 exhibits relatively higher reactivity for CH4 to oxygenates, the total space time yield (STY) of C1 oxygenates reaches up to 3434 μmol g−1 h−1 with a turnover frequency (TOF, which is defined as the moles of C1 oxygenates of CH3OH, CH3OOH and HOCH2OOH generated on one mole of Cu in one hour) of 111 h−1 (Fig. 1C and Table 1). At the same time, neither CO nor CO2 is detectable even prolonging the reaction time to 6 h (Figs. S5 & S6), suggesting the high selectivity and efficiency of the Cu2@C3N4-D catalysts, which is important for the oxidation reaction to avoid deep oxidation. As the TOF on Cu(NO3)2 is only 3.2 h−1, CH4 oxidation is significantly accelerated by two orders of magnitude over Cu2@C3N4-D1, which may be attributed to the unique features of diatomic Cu pairs confined by the support and the metal-support interactions. When the Cu loading rate is doubled (i.e., from 0.20 to 0.38 wt%), Cu2@C3N4-D2 posts a much higher STY (4878 μmol g−1 h−1) with a TOF of 83 h−1. In comparison, the single atomic catalysts, Cu1@C3N4-D1 and Cu1@C3N4-D2, offer much lower STY (1261 and 1564 μmol g−1 h−1) and TOF (54 and 34 h−1) than their diatomic counterparts. Therefore, the improved activity of Cu2@C3N4-D suggests that the interactions between Cu···Cu pair remarkably impact the catalytic performance. To investigate the carbon source of C1 oxygenates, CH4 was replaced by N2 or 13CH4 in the reaction, respectively (Fig. S7). No C1 oxygenate products were observed, suggesting that carbon source in either catalyst or reactor do not involve in the formation of target products. On the other hand, the isotope reaction via using 13CH4 as reactant proves that the C1 oxygenates were solely originated from CH4 rather than other carbon sources, which also indicates the chemical stability of Cu2@C3N4-D catalyst.

In addition, the single atomic Cu on the regular C3N4 (Cu1@C3N4) was prepared to analyze the influence of Nvac on the catalytic performance, which exhibits similar reactivity (STY of 1266 μmol g−1 h−1 and TOF of 45 h−1) to Cu1@C3N4-D1 (Table S1). It evidences that Nvac itself does not contribute to the activity. Therefore, the role of Nvac is providing spacing for Cu anchoring, which will be proved by the calculations hereinafter. The effects of Nvac density on the loading of Cu as well as the reactivity were investigated by reducing the defect formation time from 6 h to 2 and 4 h (named as C3N4-D1–2 and C3N4-D1–4, respectively). As less Nvac sites were formed, the content of Cu on C3N4-D1–2 and C3N4-D1–4 was limited to 0.10 and 0.15 wt%, respectively. The STY for C1 oxygenates of Cu2@C3N4-D1–2 and Cu2@C3N4-D1–4 decreased to 2455 and 3037 μmol g−1 h−1 with TOFs at 153 and 127 h−1, respectively (Table S1). Compared with the reported catalysts, these Cu2@C3N4-D catalysts display superior reactivity to that of the state-of-the-art catalysts, even including Pt, Rh, Au and Pd based noble metal catalysts (Table S1) [10,39,40].

The stability of Cu1@C3N4-D1 and Cu2@C3N4-D1 for CH4 oxidation was investigated by recycling the catalysts (Fig. 1D). During 5-times recycling, both catalysts exhibit very stable reactivity with steady TOFs at 51–53 h−1 for Cu1@C3N4-D1 and 109–112 h−1 for Cu2@C3N4-D1. It reveals that the diatomic Cu species fixed in the C3N4-D frameworks, which are stable enough for the reactions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structure and texture of Cu2@C3N4-D catalysts
ce:section.ce:para:
To evaluate the possibility of C3N4-D for anchoring di-atomic Cu, the charge states and binding energy of Cu2@C3N4-D were calculated by using one unit of C3N4-D. As shown in Fig. 2A, the iso-surfaces of N atoms and the C atoms neighboring Nvac are negatively charged. Thus, they donate electron to the positive charged Cu2+ and form stable electron donor-acceptor pairs, leading to strong binding states of Cu-N and Cu-C. As shown in Fig. 2B, the thermodynamic stabilities of the catalysts were further investigated by binding energy (E b) calculations: [41].
E

E
Cux @ substrate
−
E

Cu
where E Cux@substrate is the total energy of metal atoms embedded on substrate, E substrate is the total energy of substrate, and E Cu is the energy of single Cu atom from bulk phase. In the case of a single Cu atom on defect-free or defective substrates (i.e., Cu1@C3N4 and Cu1@C3N4-D), the calculated E b values are both negative, indicating that the formation of single Cu atom on either C3N4 or C3N4-D is a thermodynamically favorable process. Moreover, the formation of Cu1 @C3N4-D is much easier than that of Cu1@C3N4 due to the more negative E b of Cu1@C3N4-D (−1.7 eV vs. −0.8 eV). On the other hand, E b of Cu2 @C3N4-D is − 0.7 eV, revealing that the formation of diatomic copper on C3N4-D frameworks is also a thermodynamically feasible process. But E b is much higher than that of Cu1 @C3N4-D (−1.7 eV), suggesting that additional energy (e.g., photoirradiation in this work) is needed to prepare Cu2@C3N4-D. In contrast, E b of Cu2@C3N4 is high as 1.0 eV, suggesting a thermodynamically unfavorable process for forming diatomic copper on defect-free C3N4. Therefore, both Nvac and photoirradiation are necessary for obtaining diatomic Cu catalysts on C3N4 frameworks. The simulations suggest that it is easier to coordinate single atom than diatom by C3N4-D. Thus, it is reasonable that the real Cu2@C3N4-D catalyst contains both single Cu atoms and diatomic Cu pairs. The reactivities of Cu2@C3N4-D recorded in Fig. 1C and Table 1 are the apparent values contributed by the single atomic sites and diatomic sites. Eliminating the productivity generated from the single atomic Cu sites, thus, the rest diatomic Cu pairs fixed on C3N4-D in fact offer even higher reactivity for CH4 oxidation with much larger STYs and TOFs than the recorded values.

The microstructure of Cux@C3N4-D was investigated by aberration-corrected high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF STEM) (Fig. 2C-E). Due to the contrast between the light (C and N) and heavy (Cu) elements, the dark grey background is ascribed to the C3N4-D matrix while the scattered bright dots are attributed to Cu atoms in the high-resolution STEM image. For Cu2@C3N4-D1, Cu atoms uniformly distribute on C3N4-D and most of them (marked by blue dash) are present in pairs (Fig. 2C and S8). This directly demonstrates that Cu atoms are fixed in C3N4-D as couples. With higher loading rate of Cu, the density of Cu atom on Cu2@C3N4-D2 becomes higher (Fig. 2D and S9). In contrast, most Cu atoms are isolated as single atom on Cu1@C3N4-D1 (Fig. 2E and S10). In Cu2@C3N4-D1, the Cu distance within the diatomic pair is in the range of 0.17–0.25 nm (Fig. 2F), in line with the calculated value in Fig. 1B. Moreover, the line scan analysis reveals that the average distance between the Cu atoms is ~0.25 nm for Cu2@C3N4-D2 (Fig. 2G). It indicates that most Cu atoms also existed as ensembles diatomic pairs rather than 3D stacking texture in Cu2@C3N4-D2. Elemental mapping on Cu2@C3N4-D1 reveals that noncontinuous signals of Cu are observed apart from the main elements of C and N (Fig. 2H). It reveals that Cu atoms are highly dispersed and the bright part in the TEM image of Fig. 2H is the overlayer of C3N4-D1 nanosheets, in line with the STEM results. The XRD patterns of C3N4-D show a declined intensity of the (002) reflection compared to that of the pristine C3N4 because the exfoliation of C3N4-D increases its disorder degree (Fig. S11). All the samples, including C3N4-D, Cu2@C3N4-D1, Cu2@C3N4-D2 and Cu1@C3N4-D1, exhibit the same diffraction positions at 2θ = 27.5°, reflecting a d value of 0.32 nm [42–44]. This suggests that the interlayer stacking structure of C3N4 is well maintained upon the thermal treatment and Cu anchorage. No signals of Cu based crystals are observed due to the ultrahigh dispersion of Cu species or the low content of Cu beneath the detection limit.

The coordination states of Cu in Cu2@C3N4-D1, Cu2@C3N4-D2, and Cu1@C3N4-D1 were determined by the Cu K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy. As X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) shown in Fig. 3A, the Cu2O curve shows Cu (I) 1s→4p + L shakedown peak at 8982 eV. CuO curve has feature peaks around 8978, 8986, and 8998 eV, in which the former two signals are attributable to dipole-forbidden Cu (II) 1s→3d electronic transition and Cu (II) 1s→4p + L shakedown transition [27]. In comparison, the feature peaks of Cu₂@C₃N₄-D1, Cu₂@C₃N₄-D2, Cu1@C₃N₄-D1 locate in the range of 8982 (Cu (I)) to 8986 eV (Cu (II)). Similarly, the midpoint energies are 8980.0, 8984.0, 8984.5, 8985.0, and 8988.1 eV for Cu2O, Cu₂@C₃N₄-D1, Cu₂@C₃N₄-D2, Cu1@C₃N₄-D1, and CuO, respectively (Fig. 3A). The midpoint energies of the copper in the diatomic catalysts fall in between 8980.0 and 8988.1 eV of Cu2O and CuO, suggesting a valence state in the range of Cu(I) and Cu(II). Moreover, from the first derivation of XANES spectra (Fig. 3B), Cu2@C3N4-D1, Cu2@C3N4-D2 and Cu1@C3N4-D1 display similar absorption edge energies, which are higher than that of Cu2O (Cu(I)) but lower than that of CuO reference materials (Cu(II)). This suggests the valence state of Cu species in the catalysts are in the between of Cu (I) and Cu (II), in line with the analysis of Fig. 3A. From the Fourier transformed (FT) k3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of the samples, the main peak at R = ~1.61 Å of Cu2@C3N4-D1 and Cu2@C3N4-D2 corresponds to the bond distance of ~1.96 Å (i.e., based on the empirical equation of R + 0.35 Å), which is consistent with a first coordination shell of Cu formed with N or C (1.9–2.0 Å) (Fig. 3C) [45,46]. In comparison, the bond distance for Cu-N coordination in Cu1@C3N4-D1 slightly shifts to ~1.98 Å, indicating the different coordination to Cu2@C3N4-D1. Additionally, the weak signals of Cu-Cu bonds can be observed on spectra of Cu2@C3N4-D1 and Cu2@C3N4-D2 (Fig. S12). It confirms the atomic dispersion of Cu on C3N4-D, in line with the TEM and XRD measurements. On the other hand, the fitting results in Fig. 3D and Table S2 suggest that Cu–N/Cu–C coordination numbers (CNs) are similar in Cu2@C3N4-D1, Cu2@C3N4-D2 and Cu1@C3N4-D1 with values of 3.3–3.4, which are close to the simulated value (i.e., Cu–N = 3 in Fig. 1B). Therefore, this further supports that Cu existed as well-separated and nearly + 1 charged atoms in these catalysts.

The electronic interactions between Cu and C3N4-D were further characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The peaks at 284.6, 285.8 and 288.1 eV in the C 1s spectra are ascribed to the sp2-hybridized adventitious carbon (C–C), C-NHx on the edges of the tri-s-triazine unit, and the carbon atom in the triazine ring of C3N4 (N–CN), respectively ( Fig. 4A) [47]. Using the external carbon (C–C) as reference, the ratio of C–N/C–C on C3N4-D (1.0) is much lower than that on pristine C3N4 (1.4) owing to the formation of Nvac (Fig. S13) [37]. Upon Cu loading, a new peak appears on Cu2@C3N4-D at 283.5 eV, which is ascribed to Cu–C [46]. In contrast, no signal of Cu–C is observed for Cu1@C3N4-D1, confirming that C atoms were not involved with the fixation of single atomic Cu. Compared to the electro-positive carbon (i.e., N–C(+)-N) in C3N4, the electro-positivity of C atoms neighboring Nvac become weak in C3N4-D, which is further turned to negative by accepting electrons under the irradiation. Thus, the electron rich C atoms are involved in the anchoring of the second Cu2+ by forming Cu–C bonds, as simulated in Fig. 2A. In comparison with C3N4-D, both Cu2@C3N4-D1 and Cu1@C3N4-D1 showed a decrease of N–CN species and an increase of C–NHx species, which further confirm that the Cu species were embedded into the ring of tri-s-triazine and coordinated with the sp2-bonded N atoms [29].

The N 1s spectrum of C3N4-D was deconvoluted into three peaks at 398.8, 399.9 and 401.2 eV, corresponding to the sp2-hybridized N in the triazine ring (C–NC), sp3-hybridized N (N–C3) and amino groups (C–N–H), respectively (Fig. 4B) [29,48,49]. The binding energies of all N species on C3N4-D are 0.2 eV higher than that of C3N4 as the formation of Nvac reduced the electron density of N (Fig. S14) [38]. After loading Cu, a new peak appears at 397.5 eV, ascribed to Cu-N [50]. It confirms that the single Cu atom was anchored by Cu–N bonding in Cu1 @C3N4-D1 while the second Cu atom was fixed by both Cu–N and Cu–C interactions in Cu2@C3N4-D1. Moreover, the fraction of C–NC in the N 1s spectra slightly decreased from 69% (C3N4-D) to 65% (Cu2@C3N4-D1) and 61% (Cu1@C3N4-D1) due to the coordination between N and Cu (Fig. 4B). The Cu 2p XPS spectra of the Cu2@C3N4-D1 and Cu1@C3N4-D1 showed peaks at 933.0 eV and 952.9 eV without binding energy shift, suggesting the same state of Cu+ in these samples (Fig. 4C) [51,52], in line with the EXAFS results. Combining texture analysis with simulations, it clearly explains the formation of single Cu atom and double Cu atoms on the C3N4-D (Fig. 4D). Cu2+ loaded on C3N4-D with irradiation can bond with either three sp2-bonded N or two C next to Nvac plus one sp2-bonded N, leading to diatomic Cu in the ring of tri-s-triazines (i.e., Cu2@C3N4-D1). Further increasing the concentration of N vacancies, more copper pairs were fixed around the defects rich zone to form Cu2@C3N4-D2. Without light irradiation, Cu2+ only coordinated with three sp2-N atoms to form Cu1@C3N4-D1.

The changes of Cu2@C3N4-D after reactions were also investigated by BET, XRD, XPS and XAS (Figs. S15-S18). These results suggest that the spent catalyst basically maintains the specific surface area, diffraction structure, surface chemistry and the coordination environment, which is consistent with the catalytic reaction results.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Evolution of reaction process over Cu2@C3N4-D
ce:section.ce:para: Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was employed to probe the intermediates of CH4 oxidation (Fig. S19). Intensive radical signals of·OH,·CH3 and·OOH was detected in the Cu2@C3N4-D1 reaction solution [53–57], confirming its high activation for both H2O2 and CH4. The·OOH and·OH radicals were produced from H2O2, which then attacked C-H bonds of CH4 to form·CH3 and further produce CH3OH, CH3OOH, and HOCH2OOH [53,58]. The interactions between CH4 and the catalysts were investigated by CH4 temperature-programmed desorption (CH4-TPD) with mass spectrometry (Fig. S20). CO2, CO and H2O signals suggest that CH4 were activated by Cu2@C3N4-D1 and then reacted with the surface oxygen species of catalysts [59]. The sharp CO signal at 475–500 °C is attributed to the depletion of surface oxygen on the catalysts. In contrast, C3N4-D shows much lower activity in the EPR and CH4-TPD measurements, in line with the results of real reaction.

To gain insights into the CH4 oxidation, the reaction mechanism on Cu1@C3N4-D and Cu2@C3N4-D was investigated by DFT calculations ( Fig. 5). Cu1@C3N4-D was first activated by H2O2 to form Cu-O (−0.12 eV) (i), and then the adsorption (−0.16 eV) and the dissociation of CH4 (1.40 eV) took place on the O end of Cu-O (ii-iv). -CH3, generated from the intermediate (H-O-CH3) (−1.31 eV), was then reacted with H2O2/H2O to form CH3OH (−1.73 eV), CH3OOH (−2.63 eV), and OHCH2OOH (−3.60 eV) (v), respectively (Fig. 5A). In contrast, CH4 can directly adsorb on Cu2@C3N4-D (−0.16 eV) and then dissociate into Cu–CH3 and Cu–H (1.14 eV) (ii-iv). The -CH3 species formed from the disbanding of Cu-CH3 (−0.20 eV) further reacted with H2O2/H2O to form CH3OH (−2.58 eV), CH3OOH (−3.48 eV), and OHCH2OOH (−3.60 eV) (v), respectively (Fig. 5B). Additionally, the single Cu atom on defect-free C3N4 (Cu1@C3N4) was also simulated (Fig. S21), which exhibits a similar reaction process to that of Cu1@C3N4-D. As shown in the energy profiles, the dissociation of first C-H is the rate determining step for the CH4 oxidation on the simulated catalysts (Fig. 5C and Fig. S21). The barrier on Cu2@C3N4-D, Cu1@C3N4-D and Cu1@C3N4 was 1.14, 1.40 and 1.32 eV, respectively, accounting for the highest activity of Cu2@C3N4-D among these catalysts.

In summary, the diatomic Cu pairs confined in the Nvac containing C3N4 frameworks have been realized through a simple and facile photo-irradiation. With this strategy, the carbon atoms neighboring Nvac turn to electronegative and can anchor the second Cu ion in C3N4 frameworks. The resultant diatomic Cu2 @C3N4-D catalysts exhibited ultrahigh reactivity for the methane selective oxidation to C1 oxygenates at 50 °C, which are much higher than that of single atomic Cu1@C3N4-D catalysts as well as the reported single atomic catalysts. The mechanical and chemical stability of Cu2@C3N4-D was also proved. Both experimental analyses and computational simulations demonstrate that the diatomic Cu pairs were toughly packed in an asymmetrical texture of [N3-Cu]···[Cu-C2N] with nearly + 1 charge for each Cu atom, which endows the catalyst with differ synergistic effects on the activation and dissociation of CH4. Our findings not only provide a successful example to improve CH4 oxidation under mild conditions, but also enlighten the functionalization of elemental defects for effective catalysis.

N. Y. and G. Z. conceived the idea and designed experiments. N. Y. performed the experiments and Y. Z. performed the DFT calculations. N. Y., F. S., J. M. and Z. J. performed the XAS experiments and analysis. N. Y. and G. Z. wrote the manuscript. All the authors contributed to the data interpretation, discussion, and manuscript revision. All authors have given approval to the final version of the manuscript. N. Y. and Y. Z. contributed equally.
